conclusion: Determine both the instantaneous value of the induced current and the average value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) during the specified rotation.
The induced EMF in a rotating coil is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = B S \omega \sin(\theta) \).
At the start, the coil is in the position shown in the figure, where the normal to the coil is perpendicular to the magnetic field (\( \theta = 0^\circ \)).
After rotating through an angle of \( 60^\circ \), the angle \( \theta \) becomes \( 60^\circ \).
The instantaneous EMF when the coil has rotated through \( 60^\circ \) is: \( \mathcal{E} = B S \omega \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \).
The induced current \( I \) is given by Ohm's law: \( I = \frac{\mathcal{E}}{R} \).
The induced current is \( I = \frac{B S \omega \sqrt{3}}{2R} \).
The average induced EMF over one complete cycle is zero because the EMF is sinusoidal and symmetric about the x-axis.
The time interval for \( 60^\circ \) rotation is \( \frac{\pi}{3\omega} \).
The average EMF is \( \frac{3 B S \omega}{2\pi} \).
The instantaneous value of the induced current is: \( \frac{B S \omega \sqrt{3}}{2R} \).
The average value of the induced EMF during the process is: \( \frac{3 B S \omega}{2\pi} \).
